Hill County 1
Executive Summary


Havre Pipeline Company (HPC), owner and operator of the Hill County 1, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  The policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Hill County 1 facility, located approximately 8 miles south of Havre in Hill County, Montana, operates a propane refrigeration plant to extract liquid petroleum products from raw natural gas.  The plant products include pipeline quality natural gas (primarily methane) and natural gas liquids comprised of ethane, propane, butane, pentane, and heavier hydrocarbons, some of which are regulated flammable substances.  The process to represent all regulated flammable substances at the Hill County 1 facility which contain above the threshold quantity is as follows:

¿Product Storage Tank comprised of C2+ mixture

General Accident Release Prevention and Program Information

Hill County 1 is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP).  Hills County 1 is not considered to be a PSM facility.  Hill County 1 is classified as a "normally unoccupied remote facility" as per the definition found in 29 CFR 1910.119(b) and thus is not applicable to PSM requirements according to 29 CFR 1910.119(a)(2)(iii).  However, should this status change, Hill County 1 must be re-evaluated for PSM applicability.      

HPC encourages employees to participate in safety and accident prevention.  Employees have access to facility accident prevention program. HPC keeps a variety of technical docum

ents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.    

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs).  Hill County 1 also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing maintenance activities.

HPC has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Hill County 1 maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed.  

Personnel are properly trained according to the facility operating procedures for process operations. Hill County 1 has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations.  Refresher training is conducted on an as needed basis.  All of this training is documented for each operator.

All maintenance personnel should be aware that the equipment may contain flammable hydrocarbons, high pressure gasses & liquids; hot surfaces may be present and there may be other hazards at the site.  All personnel must review SDS sheets if they are not familiar with the substances at the site.  Be sure to contact a HPC representative and ask them about these and all other hazards that may be at this site. 

All inspections and testing will be carried out using established procedures.  

All records concerning maintenance will be kept on file by a HP

C representative.

HPC investigates incidents that result in, or reasonably could result in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.

Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at the Hill County 1 have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Hill County.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Hill County 1 has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.	Tanks are gauged
2.	Tanks/vessels are equipped with level and pressure sensors
3.	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms and shutdowns
4.	High/Low alarms and shutdowns

Release Containment/Control

1.	Berms around tanks
2.	Process relief valves venting vapors to the atmosphere to prevent vessels from rupturing
3.	Process relief valves that vent to a stack vent
4.	Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
5.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
6.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

Release Mitigation

1.	Trained emergency response personnel
2.	Personal protective eq

uipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3.	SPCC Plan
4.	Fire extinguishers

Emergency Response Program Information

The Hill County 1 maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to the release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.

The overall emergency response program for the Hill County 1 is coordinated with the Hill County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Hill County 1 has around-the-clock communications capability.  HPC operators are automatically called in the event of a process upset.  The operator will then call the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick respons

e to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, HPC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Hill County 1 provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  

Five - Year Accident History

The Hill County 1 Plant has had no accidents in the last five years; therefore the accident history has no bearing on the program determination.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A PHA will not be conducted because Hill County 1 is not a PSM facility.  HPC, owner and operator of the Hill County 1, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  HPC's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 

Record Keeping

The owner or operator of the Hill County 1 should maintain this documentation supporting the implementation of the RMP for five years (40 CFR part 68.200).
